speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Alrighty. We'll go ahead and get started then. So, hello and thank you for coming to share your story with us today as part of the Children of the Struggle Oral History Collection. We are at New Day Christian Church in Morganton, North Carolina on Saturday, November 9th, 2024. And we are talking with Ms. Doris Fullwood. My name is Alex Bouk, I'll be your primary interviewer. We also have in the room Keya Nandi and Ethan Scheurich. So Keya will be kind of like my backup, if there's anything I miss, she'll kinda ask you some questions. Ethan's gonna take some notes just so we have like a good documentation of the order of this interview for, um, when we put it in, like written format. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>. Um, we are all students at Appalachian State University and we are conducting these interviews as part of a class project. We have a standard set of 22 questions and we may or may not get through all of them depending on what you'd like to share with us. If there's any question you prefer not to answer, we'll be happy to move on to another one. Again, we wanna thank you so much for your participation and let's get started. Alright. So would you tell us your name and if you had a nickname or went by a different name when you were in school?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yes, I certainly will. My name is Doris Luck Fullwood. Uh, Luck is my maiden name. And, uh, to some I am known as Anne because I grew up as Doris Anne.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Doris Anne, very beautiful.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: That's the reason that's all written there.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yes. Thank you so much. Um, you were a teacher or a student during desegregation?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I was a teacher.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: A teacher. And what did you teach?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I taught biology and math. And physical ed.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Did you have a preference on a subject to teach?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Oh, I loved teaching Biology.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Biology, yeah. Yeah, that's a good one. Um, do you remember what it was like being black in Burke County as a child?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I was not a child in Burke County.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Oh.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I actually came here as a first year teacher, um, at the all black school, which was Olive Hilll High School at the county. So I did not experience being, well, a student in, in Burke County.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Where did you come from? Where did you come from teaching?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: So I was in Randolph County. I went to, uh, an all black school. And, uh, felt very comfortable because we didn't know any difference at the time.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: And, uh, it was a good setting. I had a good support from family and, uh, the school staff with expectations for behavior and academics.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Most definitely. Yeah.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Okay. Um, so now we're gonna move on to a different section of the interview with the questions. So when you found out you'd be going to work at a school with white and black children, how did you feel? And did anything, like any family members or parents influence your feelings?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Not really, because, um, having grown up in a very nurturing environment, uh, both in Asheboro and I went to an all-women college for women, which actually helped to give you that self-esteem. Yeah. I felt comfortable.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Awesome. Okay. Um, and what were the general feelings in your community when this happened?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Uh, of course there were people who were against it. On both, from both sides.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Yeah.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: But, uh, the faculty, we made it work.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: We've heard from some students that eventually everything kind of mellowed out. Did that reflect on the staff and the faculty at your school?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Sure. Mellowed out.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Like everyone kind of eventually got along and we were just all kind of together. Did that ever, did that reflect in the staff and faculty?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yeah, I would say. I would say so.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: It became an accepted thing. This is the way it is. And, uh, we'll go from there. Uh, I don't know if this is in your questions, but one of the things that uh, concerned me was that students who would've been recognized in the all black school students who would run for the president of the student government and, you know, leading in the choir, and those kinds of experiences did not happen, uh, for many students once, uh, desegregation occurred. That's, that's one of the things that, uh, concerned me.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I felt that there was students who fell through the cracks.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah. Yeah.
Again, um, growing up and working in the environment that I did, there were expectations. I felt that, many times, black students were not expected to one excel.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Okay. Um, and again, if there's any questions that we don't ask and you want to share, please feel free. Um, do you wanna move on to the next question. We are right here.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah. Sorry. I'm just like all over the place. Um, what was the transition from teaching at an all black school to teaching an integrated school? Like, was there any big changes for you? Other than the people <laugh>

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I'll tell you one of the things that happened, um, I'm gonna back up and give you a little backstory.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I feel privileged that I was able to see the evolution of education in Burke County. I came as a young teacher, worked in the all black school. I was a part of the desegregation process that just didn't happen.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: You know, it took several years. And then the consolidation of schools, school boards and schools. Because I was at Olive Hill, I went to Oak Hill and then with the consolidation of schools, I went to Freedom High School. So that brought a different, uh, group of students, students who had never been, uh, in a school with black kids.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: For instance, Salem was an all white school. Um, so prior to going into Freedom where the consolidation had occurred, um, there were workshops for the teachers, um, as to how we were to work with the, uh, diversity of the students. Um, I spoke to a woman recently and told her that I remember her in our workshops. She did not like me then, but I have a relationship with her now, that I could say this. In fact, it's been about two weeks till I told her. So she said, well, what did I do? Thinking I would say but of course I would not, it was just her air that, uh, she did not want to be there. This was a white teacher. But again, I have developed a relationship, in fact, she called me last week to see how I was doing with, uh. Because a tree fell on our house, and we are not in our house. But anyway, that was one of my stories.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: One of the experiences. Thank you for that. Um, and I had a question, but were there any changes in resources? Would you say like, were um, books better in different schools?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Oh, absolutely.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Can you elaborate on any of that?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yeah. At the all black school, the books were used books, uh, sometimes you know where you wrote the name of the student in the book, all the spaces would be filled. All the athletic equipment, the um band uniforms all came from white school that were used, they were not new. Okay. And then, you know, during the desegregation you saw those resources that, uh, other students have been exposed to.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>. And do you think that your students in the integrated schools, they received those resources, even though the newer ones were there, did they receive them equally, do you think?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I'm sorry?

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Um in the integrated schools, afterwards, do you think that: yes, there were more resources and they were distributed equally?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Oh yeah!

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Yes, okay.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Good. Um, in your observation of your students, how were relationships between black and white children in your school?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Uh, they were just fine.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah. They all got along pretty good?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Both with me and my students? Yeah.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Or the, between the students?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Oh, between the students! Uh, I guess the first couple of years it was difficult. One thing at one of the schools I worked in at Oak Hill High School, again, teaching science and math, um, the principal made the difference. It was an outstanding principal that did not tolerate no stuff going on. And I think he was the, um, catalyst for making it work at, at that particular school. And, and, uh, that was, let me see how many years this was after they actually did desegregated schools. Okay '65, maybe. Maybe, well. Yeah, in the next few years he was the catalyst that made it work at that particular school. I'm not so sure that all that happened at the other school 'cause you're gonna hear some other stories.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yeah. There are a lot of stories there.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Right. Um, could you tell us about a typical day in school before the integration processes started? Like at, um, Olive Hill. Olive Hill. Yes, sorry, I'm getting all my hills mixed up. What was a day in life at Olive Hill?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Well, let's say we had home room, as a teacher, I had a home room class. I have a picture of how my room was. Um, the bell rang. We exchanged, you know, not exchanged but changed classes. Um, just like a typical high school.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Just like a typical high school. Yeah. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yeah. Okay. And, uh, uh, the, you had hour, one hour periods. Um, students moved through the hall. And, uh, my first year we had a principal that did not. I'm talking about two different principals, because he did not tolerate ridiculous behavior. <laugh>. And I'm sure my husband is telling a story about what happened to him because he had gone to Olive Hill and his interaction with the principal, I'm sure he will tell it. But, uh, again, the, uh, the day was, was just like any other day.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: And so you would say it didn't change after?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yeah.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Okay. Perfect. Um, what kind of resources did your school provide to you before integration in terms of professional development? You talked about, um, work, like workshops and stuff. Were there any kind of things like that for you? Not until afterwards?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Not until afterwards. Okay. And as a department chair, at, um, at Freedom. And this was in [inaudible] I was department chair, so I actually had funds that I could control for, along with the staff, for equipment, um, workshops. Um, I mean, we had a pretty good, a good setting.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: So, yeah. So you would say that you actively participated in creating some of those workshops, do you think?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Oh, yes!

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Okay. Awesome.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: In fact, again, and this is over, let see 73-74, um, when Freedom High opened. Um, I actually helped write the curriculum for the biology department. And, uh, we, we were, um, on quarter system. And so, um, students would change teachers sometimes, uh, at the, at the end of a quarter and so we, we wrote them biology curriculum, for that setting

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: To cater to that system?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yeah! Yep, yep. So I helped in writing, and I did workshops and, and even after, after <inaudible> That's just like I said, I've had so many experiences over the years. So, um, I actually worked at [inaudible] and uh, again, did workshops for teachers and, um, and coordinated stuff.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Um, did you deal with any difficult teachers during that period or when you were advising?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Oh of course.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Oh, of course. Okay. Oh, um, can you share any experiences again?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I think once you establish yourself, the respect comes. When you respect the individuals, they will respect you. And I think I established, and I don't mean sound cocky, but a level of confidence and then that helped me being accepted.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Yeah. Okay. Yeah. That's good to know.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Um, and, and again, we're talking about over a, well, how many years? About 10?

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: About 10. Yeah.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: And, and, and those changes were going on in, in the county. Uh, not just desegregation, but also the consolidation of those schools. Where there had been no black kids in schools, you know. Does that make sense?

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah, yeah. Um, what kind of support system did you and your students have for education specifically before, um, desegregation?

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Um, and by this we mean like, were there administrators that they particularly felt close, um, depending on, or churches that they were attending and the pastors influenced them a lot, if that makes sense? Communities that influenced them outside of school?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Oh, absolutely. Um, the black community and the black churches are, and were very, um, instrumental in what was going on students, because back then kids went to, went to church. They had that, yeah. One of the things that really impressed me when I first went to Olive Hill, I worked at the school, was that the parents went to the prom.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Hmm. Oh, cool.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yeah. I thought that was really neat. You know, everybody got dressed up and, and, and went to the prom.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Um, and after integration, did this change do you think?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yes, I don't think parents were, uh, as involved. Um, and, and over the years, I don't know how it's changed 'cause I've been out about 20 something years. But, uh, I did not see the involvement of African American parents. And, uh, unless something happened that you had to come. In fact, one of my best friends, have you ever been to Freedom Hill High school? Okay. Now, first off, there were no walls. There were very limited walls. You cannot imagine <laugh>. Anyway, I have a friend, a very close friend who told me she hated to go in that building, the Freedom High School. It was so intimidating, that openness. If you can imagine no walls.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: No. Yeah.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Wow. Very limited walls.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Wow. Yeah. <laugh>

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: So, so I was, I was teaching next to my friend Steven [inaudible], and he was teaching next to Nelda. And, uh, sometimes our subjects were coordinating and we really worked together as a team. And sometimes he would teach my class, sometimes I would teach his class. And so I always said I felt like I became a better teacher because of the setting we were in, that forced us to work together. I thought I was pretty good anyway, you can tell. Yeah. But I felt that I became a better teacher because of that, um, corporation that was developed.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Right. Yeah. That's cool to know.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Is there any, um, person that really stands out to you from your experience in segregated and desegregated schools?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Well, Bill Gray, who was the principal of Oak Hill High School.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: And that's the exemplary principal you were talking about earlier. Okay. And honestly, you were probably that person for a lot of students.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Well, I get told so.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Um, describe any tensions you remember around desegregation in your school or in the community and what came of them.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Mmm, have to think about that.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Um, and I know some of these questions are worded difficultly, so I know that one, um, previous interviewee, he spoke about how the Western Concord mothers spoke to the school board and got them transportation. So that's kind of what we mean.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: There were issues with who's gonna be a cheerleader. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah. Someone else told us about that story.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yeah. That, that was the one thing that stands out.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Okay.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Cheerleaders, how many and who, um, yeah. I don't know why that stands out or not.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: <laugh>. Um, there were two walkouts, that's why <laugh>. Yep. Yep. There were walkouts. We, so we heard from a student that was part of the walkouts. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>. Um, as a teacher, how did you feel about all this?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yep. Yep. I'm trying to think. Um, I don't remember actual walk out. I'm trying to remember. I don't remember.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: That's okay. We can come back to it if you remember anything.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yeah. Because again, that principal Bill Gray, he just did not tolerate anything in the schools and he was respected where we lived, he lived in the community. Yup.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: That's, that's really nice to hear. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I'm sure there were, I was <inaudible> and, and again, there was a, a brief period right after desegregation, that I was not in the school system 'cause I was out having babies. So <laugh> So, uh, the class of 1965 was the last class to graduate Olive Hill. I went back into the classroom in 66-67. Okay. I think I wrote down. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>. So some things, some changes had occurred. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative> during that time, that year and a half, two years, so that was our school system.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Okay. Um, describe any groups or collective events that you or your family participated in that were related to desegregation.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Of course we were members of the NAACP. And our church.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Which church was that for you?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: The Gaston Chapel. Gaston Chapel. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>, African Methodist Episcopal Church.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: And when you met with your other NAACP members, um, did y'all have meetings, uh, like weekly? Or how did they work?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: There were meetings, but I was, I was a member, but, but not an active members.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Okay. Do you remember any influential active members in your community that really stood out to you?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Um, Reverend Hunt, after I remember his first name. Um, he was, uh, the pastor at [inaudible] Chapel, AME Zion Church. And I'm sure that anybody you talk to mentioned Fleming Macintosh, you'll hear that name over and over. Yeah. And then the other part that, that I can include was my husband Allen Fullwood who was on the school board. During the late sixties, and in the early seventies.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: And, um, what, what attitude or what actions did they bring forward to the community that helped, um, not helped but kind of like convince everyone that this change was so necessary?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Well, one thing was, there was a lot of respect for, for Reverend Hunt. And, uh, also provided a place for meetings. And you'll hear this particularly with the, uh, the mothers. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>. Um, there's, I, I know you've seen that marker that there, but, uh mm-Hmm. <affirmative>.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Okay. So he allowed or kind of supported meetings.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yep, yep. He supported meeting, gave them place to meet and, um, that sort of thing.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Perfect. Okay.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: And I'm gonna think his first name in a minute.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: <laugh>. Um, yeah. We can always look it up too. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: We will figure it out. It's all good.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: And, and his son, if his son were to walk in that door right now, I'd have the biggest hug and he would tell me that you are the reason I'm majoring in biology and work in science. I get that, I get it a lot.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: That's such a nice thing to hear, it has to feel so good.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: It does. It feels so good.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Good, good.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: And I get that a lot that. You know, if you set out, I do appreciate it.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: It must be such like a, I know that teaching is like such a rewarding, um, thing to do, so it must be really rewarding still, even now.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: It is, particularly during those times. Yeah. You know, so there were kids that, again, I'm not bragging, b there were kids that I encouraged to go to college and nobody in their family had ever been to college. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>. And, uh, they will tell you today that, uh, I helped influence them.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Good, yeah.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Anyway. That's not brag. That just fact.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: I like that.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Yeah. I mean, I, oh, we are all here to kind of honor education. So this is really the point of what we're doing.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: This is kind of a really negative question, but <laugh>, did you have any experience with discrimination outside of the school environment that you'd be willing to share with us?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: So, uh, going into the Belk department store at the, um, this is the first one that comes to my mind. Uh, going into the makeup counter, the cosmetic counter. And, uh, a white woman came and she was waited on before me. That's, that's the first one that stands out. Um, there was, uh, an incident in a restaurant that I, when I worked, I would call that restaurant to order food. And, uh, somebody white would be line behind me and they would be waited on. That's, that's the most, it bothered, probably bothered me more than anything else. So, and I must say yes, some of my experiences were probably more noticeable about being a woman.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Than being black.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Okay. That was my next question. Do you think that being a woman, um, significantly impacted your experiences during all this?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I, I don't think so. During desegregation, the only thing that I would remember is when I was at the central office and administration, the, uh, men had a secretary and the women had a shared secretary.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Hmm. That had to be-

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Don't forget that!

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Don't forget that! How did these experiences shape you as an adult, either personally or in your career?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Overall, I have had very positive experiences. I would, I would say. Again, I think it goes back to respect and being, um, and, and maybe being seen as cocky. And I think again, that came from the environment I grew up in and going to an all black college for women.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Yeah. Um, is there anything that you'd to share with the younger generation, um, about your experience that you want them to remember?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Um, I'd have to think about that. Um, keep busy, stay outta trouble. That's the way I raised my, I have two adult daughters.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: And, uh, they were involved. They both went to Freedom. They probably hated that I was teaching them when they were in high school because everybody knew them. But, uh, they were involved. They were in band, they lead. Um, American Field Service. In fact, one my daughters went to Bolivia during the summer, um, for a summer program. And so being involved and, and the thing that I think parents, you need to know what's going on with your kids before, um, the principal calls and says they've been in trouble.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Um, sorry, go ahead.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Did that make sense?

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Yes, yes. Of course. Of course. That answered our question too. Um, are there any other stories or thoughts you wanna share? This is our last question. So it's kind of just whatever you wanna share with the, um, what, like, what you want on the website basically.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Okay. And maybe I, I began by saying I feel, um, privileged to have experienced the evolution of education in Burke county. Cause I, I went through it all. And, uh, wow. I, that's my story!

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yep. So, and I love Burke County. And actually again, I came here as a, as a first year teacher. I walked to school every morning, with my three inch heels. Because I was about half as big as I am right now. And I had to separate myself from the, uh, from students! But, uh, I had students that tell me, [inaudible] and, and they were being cocky. "You can tell us what to do 'cause we're as old as you." <laugh> Cause we did have some students who had come back from military.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: And back then with the GI bill, uh, they could come back and finish high school. So, I did have, uh, students in my class who were not quite as old, but close to being my age. So I, I felt that it was important for me to separate my, myself, from the students. Uh, in part, one way to do it is to dress. I went to, um, a workshop on discipline and I [inaudible]. Now you ladies, in general or partly, you will get this. But I looked at the way the teachers were dressed and I said, no wonder you have discipline problems, cause you have to separate yourself from the kids.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: And one of the ways to do it is to dress. And that's, that's one my [inaudible]. <laugh>.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: How did you dress? Like what kind of, just really formal or?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I don't know. Let's see. Well, first of all, as a woman, I couldn't wear pants.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Wow. I didn't know that!

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Yes. In 1961, I could not wear pants. So I wore lots of um dresses and wore suits. And I wore heels. Um, yeah. And I can say that I was about half as big as I am now. But anyway, I just felt that that was important. Well, I was taught that way. Yeah. Again, growing up, uh, in the environment that I grew up in and the time and the, and the college that I went to, the college I went to emphasized, uh, the way you dress, the way you carry yourself.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>,

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Um, you wouldn't believe this. I mean, schools in Grangeville, the school is still there. And if we went downtown, we had hats on and we wore gloves.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>. Wow. <laugh>. Very formal!

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: We need to adapt that. Yeah. Now people come to school in sweats

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: People show up at school in pajamas. It's like, <laugh>.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I know. I know, I know. Yeah. Yeah. But, uh, we were in, the South. We were set aside in our behavior, they way we looked, and the way we dressed. So we actually had workshops, not workshops, classes! On how to set a table. The forks and spoons.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah. Yeah.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: That was part of, uh, and a lot of kids who had come to this college didn't have, you know, didn't have that kind of background. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>. But it was there. Oh, I have stories.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Do you mind me asking what college you went to?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I went to Bennett College. Which, which is a historically black college in <inaudible>. It's still one of the few, all women schools.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah. I've heard, I've heard of them. Mm-Hmm. <affirmative>.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: And that and Spellman, they're both historically black. And then [inaudible] was across the, uh, railroad tracks. Again, yes.

speaker: Ethan Scheurich
words: Um, I, I just had this question. Um, so before desegregation like 1965-1966, what were your thoughts or what were your colleagues' thoughts on like, what you thought would happen? Like were you hopeful about it?

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Oh, yeah.

speaker: Ethan Scheurich
words: Yeah.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Well, yeah. We, we, we, we knew the differences. Yeah. And felt that, uh, uh, it was, it was needed. Yeah. Uh, they, uh, uh, it was unequal.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: And it, it was not equal. And uh, I think that's the key word that people felt, um, that uh, once, and it was separate, but it was not equal. Right. I'm trying to think if I had a microscope in my biology class. Maybe. If I did, I didn't have it on. When I was at Freedom High School, there were so many microscropes. <laugh> Because they had sets in every, every class. Yeah. And every other classroom. Yeah. So I taught biology. Yep. And loved it, loved 10th graders.

speaker: Keya Nandi
words: Thank you for sharing your story with us. Those were the, um, last of our questions.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Okay. Um, did you have anything else?

speaker: Ethan Scheurich
words: Um, no, it's okay.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: So we will send you, um, the transcription of this, of this interview just in case there's anything that you really don't want out there. We will, no worries, take it out.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: I didn't say too much. <laugh>

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: But we will send you a copy of what we've recorded and stuff just, just so you have it and it's yours. We wanna make sure your story stays your story. And if you have any questions, you can ask Dr. McKesson. You can talk to her now. You can send her an email, call, or whatever you gotta do.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Okay. Well, were there any questions that I didn't answer?

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: You pretty much hit all of our questions, which is really, we're really thankful for that.

speaker: Doris Fullwood
words: Well. I am so honored to have been asked them. And uh, well

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: It means a lot to us that you, really, that you came out today.

speaker: Ethan Scheurich
words: Yes.

speaker: Alex Bouk
words: Yeah. This has been a pretty incredible experience for us. Just in terms of like getting to hear all these stories and stuff.
[Rest is small talk about Ms. Fullwood's home being affected by the hurricane.]
